data.title: Initial implementation of RenderTargetCube for OpenGL

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
Fixes #2411.

This PR adds support for RenderTargetCube on OpenGL, with a test.

A couple of notes:
- Unfortunately the [new] test doesn't pass on OpenGL :( However, the specific part of the test that renders to a `RenderTargetCube` and then extracts the data and compares it with known-good data, passes. The part that fails is when `PlatformPresent` is subsequently called. That part is not really related to the test. It obviously should pass, but I have no idea why it doesn't. Here's the stack trace; does anyone have any ideas?

``` csharp
Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.MonoGameGLException : GL.GetError() returned InvalidEnum

   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsExtensions.CheckGLError() in C:\Users\Tim Jones\Documents\GitHub\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Graphics\GraphicsExtensions.cs:line 919
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice.PlatformPresent() in C:\Users\Tim Jones\Documents\GitHub\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Graphics\GraphicsDevice.OpenGL.cs:line 380
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice.Present() in C:\Users\Tim Jones\Documents\GitHub\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Graphics\GraphicsDevice.cs:line 509
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.OpenTKGamePlatform.Present() in C:\Users\Tim Jones\Documents\GitHub\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Desktop\OpenTKGamePlatform.cs:line 292
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game.EndDraw() in C:\Users\Tim Jones\Documents\GitHub\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Game.cs:line 526
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game.DoDraw(GameTime gameTime) in C:\Users\Tim Jones\Documents\GitHub\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Game.cs:line 684
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game.Tick() in C:\Users\Tim Jones\Documents\GitHub\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Game.cs:line 515
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.OpenTKGamePlatform.RunLoop() in C:\Users\Tim Jones\Documents\GitHub\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Desktop\OpenTKGamePlatform.cs:line 144
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game.Run(GameRunBehavior runBehavior) in C:\Users\Tim Jones\Documents\GitHub\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Game.cs:line 397
   at MonoGame.Tests.TestGameBase.Run(Predicate`1 until) in C:\Users\Tim Jones\Documents\GitHub\MonoGame\Test\Framework\TestGameBase.cs:line 185
   at MonoGame.Tests.Visual.RenderTargetCubeTest.ShouldClearRenderTargetAndGetData(Int32 size) in C:\Users\Tim Jones\Documents\GitHub\MonoGame\Test\Framework\Visual\RenderTargetCubeTest.cs:line 50
```
- In order to avoid duplicating loads of render target-related code (for `RenderTarget2D` and `RenderTargetCube`) in `GraphicsDevice.OpenGL.cs`, I have added some properties and a method to `IRenderTarget`.

data.title: Fixed #1946 Turns out the Image needs to be cleared first otherwise the colors bleed.
Removed unnecessary platform differences in MGFX

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body: This PR has a bunch of fixes to reduce the unnecessary platform differences in the MGFX format and Effect/Shader code.  This includes removal and/or reduction of `#if`s in that code and incrementing the MGFX version to 8.

data.title: Rebuild libmojoshader_64.dll to statically link against runtime
data.body:
Currently the libmojoshader_64.dll for is dynamically linked to the C runtime.  This means when libmojoshader_64.dll is loaded it looks for MVSC120.dll installed on the system.  If this version of the C runtime isn't installed you get a generic error like...

```
System.DllNotFoundException: Unable to load DLL 'libmojoshader_64.dll': The specified 
module could not be found. (Exception from HRESULT: 0x8007007E)
```

... confusing users into thinking libmojoshader_64.dll is missing when that isn't the problem at all.  See https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/4263 for more detail.

Instead we should rebuild libmojoshader_64.dll and have it statically link to the C runtime which avoids the dependency all together.

Three PRs are needed to complete this task.  The code for the version of MojoShader used by MonoGame is here:

  https://github.com/MonoGame/mojoshader

A PR should be submitted to that repo changing the C++ project to statically link as well as a PR updating the MonoGame dependencies:

 https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame.Dependencies

And a final PR to the MonoGame repo updating the submodule reference.

data.title: OpenTK: native input driver detects keyboard as 2 gamepads
data.body:
Thought this was fixed, but it looks like it isn't...

This is only Windows related. When OpenTK uses the native `WinRawJoystick`, it detects two additional gamepads which are in fact some HID ghosting of the keyboard.

data.title: Reverted and cleaned some ogg streamer changes
data.body:
Looks like #4442 fixed the remaining OggStreamer issues but the safe check I've added was unnecessary and had a little bug which made it less thread-safe.
I've reverted some changes and kept the optimization.

data.title: Fix an issue where the user is unable to change the app Icon from default MonoGame one.
data.body:
Because we explicitly use the Embedded Icon, unless a user builds
the library and changes it they cannot change the icon of the game.
While this might be nice from a MG point of view for marketing ;)
its not really desireable.

This commit adds support for looking for an "Icon.ico" file in
the applicaiton embedded resources first, then default to the
MonoGame one if needed.

data.title: Floating point values for Color do not work?
data.body:
Hello, I have found a strange issue with the `Color` class. I'm using the latest dev build of MonoGame and made an entirely new Windows Game project to make sure something from my current project does not conflict with my code and cause this issue. Consider this code in `Game1.Draw(GameTime gameTime)`:

`GraphicsDevice.Clear(new Color(231.0f, 214.0f, 90.0f, 1.0f));`

Although there are `float` overloads for `Color`, when I debug the program the color is not similar to light yellow, but it is entirely white. But if I make these `int`egers, it works fine. [Here is a side-by-side comparison in a screenshot.](http://i.imgur.com/vlm17ZM.png) Is this actually a bug or an intended behavior? I'm not so familiar with MonoGame's code implementation for `Color`, but correct me if I'm wrong, aren't `float` Color values just rounded to match `int` values, e.g. `243.2f = 243`?? This could be useful if you are getting a `float` value from arithmetic division and the framework will convert it to `int` for you, but again I'm not sure what your code implementation is, and I'm assuming that was the purpose of the `float` overloads?

data.title: High-Level classes for material, lights and shadows
data.body:
I would like to suggest some addition MonoGame could offer, as IMHO, mimicking XNA with also its lacks and flaws would be a mistake.

Working with XNA for quite a while now, I'm just disappointed by the incredible lack of high-level interface to material and light stuff. By material I mean things like Unity offer, a combination of textures and shaders parameters to create very common material look (metal, glass, wood, stone) with diffuse, normal/bump map, spec map, alpha map eventually.
Also, it's even more incredible to see how time wasting/painful could be to add simple lights and shadow in XNA (there are too much samples in fact).

Many people/companies tried and give-up now, leaving behind kind of junk-yard full of dead engines (Ploobs: not finished, full of annoying issues, SunBurn: dead, no way to get sourcecode, EngineNine: dead too, at least free and with source).

It's quite a shame XNA team never made anything, providing quite a high-level layer for basic 2D games is good (despite it doesn't include easy to use scrolling/camera/level building build-in features) but 3D is a lot more common and have more focus, I think, and all devs have to reinvent the wheel over and over every time for very basic things.

So, I would be really pleased to have some kind of BasicEffect class for common material settings, something like:

Material wood = new Material (woodtexture, specmap);

or 

Material rustymetal = new Material (metaltex, ... <other parameters here>);

The same for lights and shadows:

Light point1 = new Light(Pointtype, position, intensity, color);
point1.castshadow = true;
point1.shadowtype = smooth;

instead of thousands of code lines + HLSL for shaders .
(with an enum to specify light type or various constructors for point/spot lights).

As MG has to support many platform, it would need obviously to offer some way to the common features supported by all (the ONLY COMMON base), and very specific features (DX10/11 on windows for example) and perhaps a way to specify which PS/VS version caller want to use.

By the way, if such thing already exist, I'm really happy to see it.

data.title: Texture2D.FromStream cannot load tga files
data.body:
Reproducable with no problems in MonoGame 3.4. Take a tga file and try to load it with Texture2D.FromStream. You will get a SharpDX exception:

HRESULT: [0x88982F50], Module: [SharpDX.WIC], ApiCode: [WINCODEC_ERR_COMPONENTNOTFOUND/Componentnotfound], Message: Component not found

I need FromStream() as I have a system to load data asynchronous and transparent from local and server, so I need byte arrays.

Any chance of fixes? My workaround is using png as this seems to work properly.

data.title: Upgrade font processing
data.body:
Corrects problems detected in pull #4472. The formatting changes were detected just before writing this. I did a few tweaks to my style configuration and compared what it changed from the base directly with Visual Studio, and it highlighted a lot less lines. The changes are mainly replacing tabs with spaces, sorry about that.
This pull changes the way fonts are imported. Previously the size of the font was taken from the font autohinter, and this side has proved being wrong in some cases, see #4468 with Trebuchet MS.
Now the font gets read in its entirety to measure it.
Deleted old code from days of the GDI rasterizer that was never called in method `CreateFontFace`
Removed try... catch from method `CreateFontFace` because it catched everything to just rethrow it

data.title: Updated Dependencies to bring in updated OpenTK
Pipeline tool - missing libfreeimage.dylib
data.body: The pipeline tool of 3.5 fails at building textures on Mac if you haven't installed freeimage from brew. It would be nice to know which dependencies are needed if they're not delivered with MG.

data.title: Upgrade sharp font importer to provide fitter size for texts
data.body:
This pull changes the way fonts are imported. Previously the size of the font was taken from the font autohinter, and this side has proved being wrong in some cases, see #4468 with Trebuchet MS.
Now the font gets read in its entirety to measure it.
Also i have added the SharpFont documentation

data.title: Fix nullable enum serialization bug
data.body:
Prior to this fix, serializing or deserializing a nullable enum using `IntermediateSerializer` would crash in `NullableSerializer.Initialize` because `EnumSerializer` couldn't be cast to `ElementSerializer<T>`.

This pull request simplifies `NullableSerializer<T>` by using the existing `ReadRawObject` and `WriteRawObject` methods, which remove the need for the `List<T>` workaround.

data.title: Fix/remove ImaAdpcm support
data.body:
Currently if you use the content pipeline and set a sound file to `Medium` or `Low` quality then try to play it on MacOS or iOS you get static.  This is because for those platforms we generate compressed ImaAdpcm sound data:

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline/Processors/SoundEffectProcessor.cs#L48

At the time that code was added (https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/1232) the runtime used Mac/iOS native APIs for sound effects which supported the format.

We have since moved to using OpenAL on Mac and iOS which does not support this compressed format.

We have a few different paths here:
- Figure out if OpenAL on Mac/iOS supports playback of ImaAdpcm audio and fix the runtime.
- If OpenAL on Mac/iOS supports some other compressed format switch to that.
- Remove ImaAdpcm compression for Mac/iOS.

Note that decompressing ImaAdpcm sound effects at load time is not a solution here.  The whole point of compressing sound effects is to save system memory after it is loaded from disk.

data.body:
This PR starts to add some unit tests for `SoundEffect` while fixing bugs.  I also tried to cleanup platform initialization limiting it to one path for PCM data and another for non-PCM formats.

I cleaned up the `#if` mess in `SoundEffectReader` by moving the work into `SoundEffect` platform methods.

This needs further testing before merging.

data.title: Displaced spritefonts comparing monogame with xna
data.body:
After some days before realizing that @tomspilman said that i should make a new issue about this in pull #4439.
After many tries comparing fonts, the problem must be in the pipeline (in my project i don't use measureString so it couldn't benefit from @MichaelDePiazzi changes). I did a test program to try different fonts and the area reported by measurestring. and i get that the fonts JingJing and Lindsey from the redistributable package produce very similar results as shown here:
![jing](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11319966/12584591/936b1908-c448-11e5-9d56-6f6c01ccdc50.gif)
![linds](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11319966/12584592/94f06c7e-c448-11e5-93ed-0163d155fce9.gif)
But when using "Trebuchet MS" for example there are some problems as shown here:
![trebu](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11319966/12584732/2ddfc146-c449-11e5-9fa7-4f04700914aa.gif)
Notice the big difference in the black area (it's the reported size from measureString). And also i you zoom on the '' character you can see that it is drawn below the black box. The font has size 48, spacing 0, kerning, and character region goes from 32 to 256.

The size of each character compared to XNA is 1 pixel lower (61 to 62 for '', or 58 to 59 for '') but that may come from the different rendering method, and the out of bounds drawing comes, if i have understood correctly the Freetype documentation, from the rounding of the hinting algorithm (the face reports a height of 74, with an ascender of 60 and a descender of 14, but '' has a descender of 15).

I'm thinking that the way the fonts gets proccesed in each pipeline, is different, I'll try later to check if grabbing metrics for each character can provide different results.

data.title: Target platform identifier cleanup
data.body:
- Added feature to allow for static platform initialization in `ContentManager`.
- Clearly labeled all legacy platform identifiers.
- Added warning about console platform identifiers.

data.title: OpenTK and Steam aren't good friends
Updated README
Adding OpenAL error checking everywhere with more verbosity
SoundEffectReader Refactor
data.body:
I plan to refactor how `SoundEffectReader` constructs `SoundEffect`s.  Currently there is this crappy `#ifdef` in there:

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Content/ContentReaders/SoundEffectReader.cs#L117

Looking at it closer it seems to do nothing that couldn't be done within `SoundEffect` itself.

My strategy is to add an internal constructor that also passes the `format` into `SoundEffect` when it is not a PCM format.  Internally this would call an platform initialization method that takes a format.  This allows for platform specific audio formats to work as well as formats like PCM.

data.title: Cleanup FX syntax for shader compiler

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
This PR uses the existing MGFX parser token tree to replace all FX syntax with whitespace.  This removes the FX syntax the system already parsed so that it isn't passed thru to the shader compiler step.  By replacing it with whitespace it ensures we don't break any line number info in errors and debugging tools.

This is one more step towards GLSL support too (see https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/2167).

data.title: 4415 - GL VertexElementFormat.Short4 Bug?
data.body: This is a fix for #4415.

data.title: Pipeline filter view doesn't handle warnings well
data.body:
Sometimes tools like shader compilers will dump out `warning` messages like error messages.  Here is an example of that:

https://gist.github.com/tomspilman/f502f209178e3337bc2e

The filter view in the Pipeline tool doesn't correctly detect that as the output of one build content item.
